content: The Act titled "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for increased disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, and software for filing reports. It also addresses soft money of national political parties and contribution limits. The Act "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, and software for filing reports. It also addresses limits on soft money and contribution limits. The Act "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 regarding monthly reports for Principal Campaign Committees. Monthly reports are required, except in November and December, with a year-end report due by January 31 of the following year. The Act "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require quarterly reports for Principal Campaign Committees. Quarterly reports are due not later than the 15th day after the last day of each calendar quarter, with the report for the quarter ending December 31 due by January 31 of the following year. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require monthly reports for national committees of political parties, replacing quarterly reports. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require monthly reports for national committees of political parties, replacing quarterly reports. Section 309 is amended to change "calendar quarter" to "month" in reporting requirements. SEC. 102. REPORTING BY NATIONAL POLITICAL PARTY COMMITTEES. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require national and congressional political committees to report all receipts and disbursements during the reporting period, with itemization for amounts exceeding $200 from any person in a calendar year. The political committee must separately itemize reporting for any person aggregating over $200 in a calendar year, following the same reporting periods as required for political committees. SEC. 103 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require the Commission to make reports available on the Internet within 24 hours. SEC. 104 mandates public access to broadcasting records. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require licensees to maintain and make public a complete record of requests to purchase broadcast time related to political matters of national importance. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 now requires licensees to keep a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters of national importance, including details like acceptance/rejection, rates, air date, and purchased time class. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 mandates licensees to maintain records of requests to buy broadcast time for political matters, including details such as time class, candidate's name, election office, and requester information. Licensees must maintain records of requests to buy broadcast time for political matters, including details such as the person purchasing the time, contact person's name, address, and phone number, and a list of key executives. This information must be placed in a political file promptly and retained for at least 2 years. SEC. 105. SOFTWARE FOR FILING OF REPORTS. Section 304(a) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include the development and provision of software for filing reports at no cost to individuals required to file under the Act. Any person required to maintain or file a designation, statement, or report under paragraph (11) must use software developed under subparagraph (A) for such purposes. SEC. 201 imposes limits on soft money of national political party committees under Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. SEC. 201 imposes limits on donations to political party committees, restricting individuals from donating over $60,000 in a calendar year. The aggregate disbursements exceeding $60,000 in any calendar year are subject to an index adjustment based on the price index determined under section 315(c) after 2001. SEC. 202. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Expedited Review: Members of Congress, candidates, national party committees, or affected individuals can challenge the constitutionality of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act in the US District Court for the District of Columbia. Appeals can be made to the Supreme Court regarding injunctions or final decisions on such actions. Expedited Review: Actions brought under subsection (a) can be appealed directly to the Supreme Court of the United States. The District Court for the District of Columbia and the Supreme Court must expedite the disposition of such matters. Enforcement of section provisions is ensured. Enforcement of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, as added by section 201, will be stayed from the filing of an action under subsection (a) until the Supreme Court of the United States makes a final decision. This provision applies only to actions filed within 30 days of the Act's effective date. SEC. 203. INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTION LIMITS. Increase in contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, with individual and political committee limits raised to $3,000, $60,000, and $15,000 respectively. Additionally, the limit for paragraph 3 is increased to $75,000 with the removal of the second sentence. The contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 are increased, with individual and political committee limits raised to $7,500 and $30,000 respectively. The limit for multicandidate committees is increased to $75,000 with the removal of the second sentence. The amendment to Section 607 of title 18, United States Code, removes a reference to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 and defines "contribution" as a gift or money given in connection with elections or political committees. Amendment of Title 18 includes prohibition of donations, redefining "contribution" as a gift or money given in connection with elections or political committees. SEC. 302. UPDATE OF PENALTY AMOUNTS. Section 309 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to adjust dollar amounts for inflation after 2001 based on the price index. This adjustment does not apply to amounts under subsection (d) other than the $25,000 amount. SEC. 303. Filing of Senate reports with the Federal Election Commission. Section 302 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to specify that all required filings must be submitted to the Commission.
